    Highlights

    •
    Perturbation of the intestinal microbiome results in enhanced alphavirus infection
    •
    An altered microbiome diminishes type I IFN responses in monocytes and pDCs
    •
    Recolonization with a single Clostridium symbiont restores antiviral immunity
    •
    Secondary bile acids restore pDC and IFN responses to restrict CHIKV dissemination

    Summary

    Chikungunya virus (CHIKV), an emerging alphavirus, has infected millions of people. However, the factors modulating disease outcome remain poorly understood. Here, we show in germ-free mice or in oral antibiotic-treated conventionally housed mice with depleted intestinal microbiomes that greater CHIKV infection and spread occurs within 1 day of virus inoculation. Alteration of the microbiome alters TLR7-MyD88 signaling in plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) and blunts systemic production of type I interferon (IFN). Consequently, circulating monocytes express fewer IFN-stimulated genes and become permissive for CHIKV infection. Reconstitution with a single bacterial species, Clostridium scindens, or its derived metabolite, the secondary bile acid deoxycholic acid, can restore pDC- and MyD88-dependent type I IFN responses to restrict systemic CHIKV infection and transmission back to vector mosquitoes. Thus, symbiotic intestinal bacteria modulate antiviral immunity and levels of circulating alphaviruses within hours of infection through a bile acid-pDC-IFN signaling axis, which affects viremia, dissemination, and potentially transmission.

    ). However, a mechanistic understanding of the immune cells and signaling pathways linked to the microbiome and the identification of specific microorganisms that influence antiviral responses is lacking.
    Here, we describe the impact of the mammalian intestinal microbiome on alphavirus infection and dissemination. CHIKV infection of oral Abx-treated or GF mice resulted in increased viral burden in blood and tissues distant from the site of inoculation. These phenotypes correlated with greater infection of circulating monocytes in microbiome-depleted mice. RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) of Abx-treated mice following CHIKV infection revealed diminished expression of ISGs in blood monocytes, and this was associated with reduced levels of type I IFN in serum. Differences in CHIKV tropism following microbiome depletion depended on TLR7 and MyD88 signaling in pDCs, which regulated systemic type I IFN production within hours of infection. Colonization of Abx-treated mice with a bile acid (BA)-transforming single bacterial species, Clostridium scindens, resulted in pDC- and MyD88-dependent type I IFN responses that controlled CHIKV infection. Exogenous administration of a secondary BA to Abx-treated, GF mice, or even untreated mice, recapitulated the MyD88- and pDC-dependent protection observed with C. scindens colonization. Thus, perturbations in the intestinal microbiome or reconstitution with even a single bacterial species can modulate rapid antiviral responses through an IFN-dependent immune axis between BA-transforming bacteria and pDCs.

    Results

    Depletion of the Intestinal Microbiome Increases Systemic CHIKV Burden

    To alter the composition of the intestinal bacterial microbiome in conventionally housed mice, animals received two oral Abx, ampicillin and vancomycin (AV), or vehicle for 3 days. Antibiotics were cleared after providing antibiotic-free drinking water for 3 days prior to subcutaneous inoculation in the foot with a clinical strain of CHIKV (La Reunion OPY1, 2006) (Figure 1A). Short-term AV treatment led to diminished fecal bacteria at the time of CHIKV inoculation (Figure 1B). Profound differences in bacterial community composition were observed between AV- and vehicle-treated mice with considerable changes in beta-diversity and alpha-diversity as measured by richness (Figures S1B–S1D).
    Systemic CHIKV burden was greater in AV-treated than vehicle-treated mice as soon as 1 day post-infection (dpi). CHIKV titers were elevated in the serum and spleen, but not in the ipsilateral ankle adjacent to the inoculation site (Figure 1C). At 3 dpi, higher viral titers were detected in the serum, spleen, and contralateral ankle of AV-treated mice (Figure 1D); this pattern was associated with more persistence of CHIKV RNA in the spleen and contralateral ankle at 28 dpi (Figure 1E). Even though CHIKV titers were not increased in the ipsilateral ankle, we observed exacerbated joint swelling in AV-treated mice (Figure 1F). At 3 dpi, abundant viral RNA staining was observed in the red pulp of the spleen in AV-treated, but not vehicle-treated, mice (Figure 1G).
    To test if these virological phenotypes were due to alterations of the intestinal microbiome, we performed microbial reconstitution studies. Fecal microbial transfers (FMTs) from Abx-naive, uninfected mice into AV-treated animals that were performed at 1 day post-Abx cessation (AV+FMTs) restored total fecal 16S rRNA copy number (Figure 1B) and partially reconstituted the enteric bacterial community composition at day 0 (Figures S1B–S1D). In Abx-treated mice, the effects of the FMT reversed CHIKV titer differences in the serum, spleen, and contralateral ankle (Figures 1C and 1E), and prevented the worsened joint swelling (Figure 1F).
    To confirm a role for intestinal microbes in modulating CHIKV infection, we used a gnotobiotic mouse model. Non-colonized GF mice or GF mice colonized by FMTs from conventionally raised mice were inoculated with CHIKV. At 1 dpi, greater titers of CHIKV were detected in the serum and spleen of non-colonized GF mice than FMT-colonized GF mice, and no difference was observed in the ipsilateral ankle (Figure 1H). The concordance of findings in both GF and Abx-treated mice supports a role for the intestinal microbiome in modulating CHIKV infection at systemic sites, but not locally at the site of inoculation.

    Circulating Monocytes of Abx-Treated or GF Mice Are More Permissive to CHIKV

    Given that AV-treated mice had increased viral RNA in the red pulp of the spleen, we hypothesized that an enhanced dissemination phenotype might be due to infection of circulating myeloid cells. Indeed, viral burden was greater in peripheral blood leukocytes (125-fold) than in cell-free plasma (13-fold) in AV-treated compared to vehicle-treated mice at 1 dpi (Figures 2A and 2B). We analyzed peripheral blood leukocytes by flow cytometry to define permissive subsets using monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) against the CHIKV envelope proteins (Figures S2A and S2B). At 1 dpi, CD11b+CD115+Ly6G– monocytes had the highest levels of CHIKV antigen on their surface. Although subsets of both classical (Ly6ChiCD43−CCR2+) and patrolling (Ly6CloCD43+CCR2−) monocytes stained positively for viral antigens, only classical monocytes showed increased CHIKV antigen staining after AV treatment (Figure 2C). This phenotype also was observed in GF mice compared to FMT-colonized GF mice (Figures 2D–2F). Overall, in AV- and vehicle-treated mice, we observed no differences in the frequency or number of monocytes after CHIKV infection (Figure S2C).
    Higher levels of CHIKV antigen on the surface of Ly6Chi monocytes could reflect bound or opsonized virus rather than productive infection. To address this issue, we utilized a CHIKV-GFP reporter virus in which GFP expression occurs only following translation and replication within the cell. GFP signal was detected in Ly6Chi monocytes from AV-treated but not vehicle-treated mice (Figures 2G and 2H). This experiment confirms productive monocyte infection following alteration of the intestinal microbiome.
    To determine whether the enhanced infection of myeloid cells contributed to the increased viremia observed with AV treatment, we first depleted neutrophils and Ly6Chi monocytes with an anti-Ly6C/Ly6G mAb (Czuprynski et al., 1994
    16.
    Czuprynski, C.J. ∙ Brown, J.F. ∙ Maroushek, N. ...
    Administration of anti-granulocyte mAb RB6-8C5 impairs the resistance of mice to Listeria monocytogenes infection
    J. Immunol. 1994; 152:1836-1846
    Crossref
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) (Figures S3A and S3B). In mice depleted of neutrophils and monocytes, viremia at 1 dpi in the AV-treated group normalized to those of vehicle-treated mice (Figure 2I). Depletion of Ly6Chi monocytes alone, but not neutrophils alone, resulted in viremia in AV-treated mice that normalized to vehicle-treated mice (Figures 2J, 2K, and S3C–S3F). Thus, the microbiome modulates the permissiveness of Ly6Chi monocytes to CHIKV in blood, which affects viremia at early stages of infection.
    To determine if alterations in the intestinal microbiome also impacted viral burden in Ly6Chi monocytes during infection by another arthritogenic alphavirus, we inoculated mice with Mayaro virus (MAYV). AV-treated mice also had higher levels of MAYV in serum and peripheral blood leukocytes at 1 dpi (Figures S4A and S4B) and greater amounts of MAYV antigen on the surface of monocytes (Figure S4C).

    Changes in the Intestinal Microbiome Alter Antiviral ISG Response in Ly6Chi Monocytes

    To define how the microbiome alters the susceptibility of monocytes to infection, we performed single-cell RNA-seq of peripheral blood leukocytes in vehicle- and AV-treated uninfected and CHIKV-infected (1 dpi) mice. We enriched for myeloid cells by negative selection using antibody-coated magnetic beads. Graph-based clustering and established cell-type markers identified transcriptional groups of leukocyte subpopulations (Figure 3A) including one B cell cluster, one T cell cluster, four clusters of blood monocytes, and smaller clusters of neutrophils and NK cells (Figures S5A–S5I). We detected large transcriptional changes after CHIKV infection with expansion of one blood monocyte cluster (termed cluster “1”; Figures 3B and S5J) that essentially was absent in uninfected mice and showed significant ISG upregulation following infection. Analysis of monocytes clusters at 1 dpi (clusters 1, 2, 5, and 8) derived from AV-treated mice showed transcriptional differences from vehicle-treated controls, with decreased expression of genes in the type I IFN response pathway including Irf7 and other canonical ISGs (Figures 3B and 3C). Analysis of monocyte clusters from naive mice showed smaller differences in ISG signature between cells from AV- and vehicle-treated mice prior to infection (Figure S5K). Cells in clusters 1 and 2 express Ly6c2, Ccr2, and Csf1r mRNA, which is consistent with the classical Ly6Chi monocyte subset that we identified as more permissive to alphavirus infection following AV treatment (Figures S5A–S5C). We confirmed decreased expression of selected ISGs in sorted Ly6Chi monocytes from AV-treated mice obtained 1 day after MAYV infection (Figure 3D). Thus, depletion of the intestinal microbiome results in diminished ISG induction in peripheral blood monocytes, which likely renders these cells permissive to alphavirus infection.
    To establish whether microbiome-dependent differences in antiviral response were due to cell-intrinsic changes or altered environmental cues, we performed adoptive transfer experiments using donor monocytes harvested from AV- or vehicle-treated naive CCR2+GFP+ transgenic mice. GFP+ monocytes were sorted and transferred to recipient AV- or vehicle-treated wild-type (WT) mice (Figure 3E). Sixteen hours later, recipient mice were inoculated with CHIKV, and viral antigen expression on peripheral blood leukocytes was measured. CCR2+GFP+ Ly6Chi CD11b+ monocytes derived from AV-treated mice and transferred into AV-treated recipients showed greater CHIKV antigen staining than those derived from vehicle-treated mice and transferred into vehicle-treated recipients (Figures 3F and 3G). Transfer of CCR2+GFP+ monocytes from vehicle-treated mice into AV-treated recipients resulted in a higher frequency of CHIKV antigen-positive Ly6Chi monocytes. Reciprocally, when CCR2+GFP+ monocytes from AV-treated mice were transferred into vehicle-treated hosts, the frequency of CHIKV antigen-positive Ly6Chi monocytes was decreased. These results suggest that microbiome-dependent immune cues promote optimal antiviral responses in Ly6Chi monocytes to restrict alphavirus infection.
    We hypothesized that other cell types might fail to produce type I IFN resulting in the diminished ISG response in Ly6Chi blood monocytes. Indeed, vehicle-treated mice at 1 dpi showed a robust type I IFN response in serum following CHIKV infection, whereas AV-treated mice did not (Figure 3H). Moreover, FMTs prior to CHIKV inoculation restored the type I IFN response of AV-treated mice to those of vehicle-treated animals. Analogously, GF mice inoculated with CHIKV also had markedly lower type I IFN levels in serum than FMT-colonized GF mice (Figure 3I).
    Because of these results, we expected that the differences in viremia between AV- and vehicle-treated mice might be lost in Ifnar1−/− mice. Despite a narrowing of the phenotype, small differences at 1 dpi remained between AV- and vehicle-treated mice. These data suggest that in addition to type I IFN, other antiviral pathways might be affected by AV treatment. We next tested Stat1−/− mice, as STAT1 conveys signals downstream of type I, II (IFN-γ), and III (IFN-λ) receptor engagement. At 1 dpi, viremia was equivalent between AV-and vehicle-treated Stat1−/− mice (Figure 3J). To define whether IFN-γ contributed to the normalized viremia in AV-treated Stat1−/− mice, we treated Ifnar1−/− mice with a blocking anti-IFN-γ mAb (Harty et al., 1992
    28.
    Harty, J.T. ∙ Schreiber, R.D. ∙ Bevan, M.J.
    CD8 T cells can protect against an intracellular bacterium in an interferon gamma-independent fashion
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 1992; 89:11612-11616
    Crossref
    Scopus (117)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ); the addition of anti-IFN-γ mAb to Ifnar1−/− mice abrogated the difference in viremia between AV- and vehicle-treated groups at 1 dpi and correspondingly, IFN-γ levels were reduced in the serum of AV-treated mice (Figure 3K). Last, following AV treatment, differences in viremia at 1 dpi were also lost in conditional knockout (KO) mice lacking Stat1 only in myeloid cells (LysM-Cre+ Stat1fl/fl) when compared to littermate controls (Cre− Stat1fl/fl) (Figure 3L). Thus, viremia differences observed upon microbiome depletion depend on IFNs and Stat1 signaling in LysM+ myeloid cells, which includes monocytes.

    To dissect how the intestinal microbiome alters the antiviral function of pDCs, we interrogated expression levels of 547 immune genes using the NanoString platform in sorted splenic pDCs immediately before (day 0) or 1 day after MAYV infection. Principal component analysis showed that at 0 dpi, AV- and vehicle-treated pDCs clustered together, suggesting a limited impact of the microbiome on pDC immune gene signatures at baseline (Figure 4E). In contrast, at 1 dpi, pDCs clustered by treatment group (Figure 4E), with those from AV-treated mice expressing fewer type I IFN response gene transcripts (Figure 4F). Unbiased hierarchal clustering of genes involved in IFN responses showed transcriptional differences between AV- and vehicle-treated mice at 1 dpi, but not at day 0 in genes involved in viral sensing (e.g., TLRs and Irf7) (Figures 4G and S6D). Ifna1 and Ifna2 levels were similar between the two groups despite large transcriptional decreases in ISG expression. Because only Ifna and Ifna2 were included in the NanoString platform, we evaluated expression of Ifna4, Ifna5, and Ifna6 using qRT-PCR. Decreased (>10-fold) expression of Ifna5 and Ifna6 was observed in AV-treated mice compared to vehicle-treated controls (Figure 4H). These data show that the antiviral, but not basal, transcriptional immune response program of pDCs is altered by the intestinal microbiome.

    Microbiome-Dependent Restriction of CHIKV Dissemination Depends on MyD88 Signaling in pDCs

    We evaluated whether specific pattern recognition receptor signaling pathway(s) mediated the microbiome-dependent restriction of CHIKV infection. We observed that CHIKV burden differences in the serum, peripheral blood leukocytes, and spleen were increased in Myd88−/− vehicle-treated mice compared to vehicle-treated WT controls (Figures 5A–5C) but were equivalent between AV-treated WT and Myd88−/− mice. Correspondingly, vehicle-treated Myd88−/− mice had lower type I IFN levels in serum than WT mice, but this difference was lost in AV-treated WT and Myd88−/− mice (Figure 5D).

    Colonization with a Clostridial Bacterium Restricts CHIKV Infection

    We investigated whether specific bacterial taxa or communities mediated the protective effect of the microbiota. Based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing and analysis, colonization of AV-treated mice with FMTs re-established microbial diversity (Figure S1). However, the number of bacterial amplicon sequence variants (ASVs) that differed between the AV and AV+FMT fecal samples was too great to test for specific taxa (Figures S1B and S1C). To reduce the complexity, we inoculated mice with bulk anaerobically (ANA) cultured bacteria from our protective FMT stock. AV-treated mice receiving the FMT-derived anaerobic cultures (AV+ANA) showed enhanced viral dissemination following CHIKV infection (Figure 6A). Given that the AV+FMT group was protective but AV+ANA was not, we hypothesized that bacteria enriched in the AV+FMT versus AV+ANA likely promoted the antiviral response. Of the 34 differentially expressed ASVs that were increased in the AV+FMT group at 1 dpi (Table S1), 28 were in the Clostridiales order, 10 shared sequence identity with annotated Clostridium species, and one was related closely to Clostridium scindens (Figure 6B), a human symbiont not present in the natural mouse microbiota, which can modulate immunity through production of short-chain fatty acids and transformation of primary BA (Buffie et al., 2015

    Because CHIKV is maintained in a transmission cycle in which viremia is a determinant of vector infection, we assessed whether manipulation of the microbiome could impact transmission to the mosquito vector. Blood was harvested at 1 dpi from mice treated with vehicle or AV, or AV and colonized with C. scindens, and presented for feeding to Aedes albopictus mosquitoes. After oral engorgement by mosquitoes, CHIKV titers in the salivary gland-containing head were quantified 7 days later by quantitative real-time PCR. Mean and median viral titers were higher in mosquitoes fed on blood from CHIKV-infected AV-treated mice than vehicle-treated or AV-treated mice colonized with C. scindens (Figure 6J). A larger fraction of mosquitoes was positive for CHIKV RNA in the group exposed to blood from AV-treated (17 of 32) than vehicle-treated (11 of 39) or C. scindens-colonized (7 of 34) mice (Figure 6K). Thus, in the setting of an altered microbiome, colonization of mice with C. scindens can limit CHIKV viremia in a mammalian host and prevent transmission back to the mosquito vector.

    Oral administration of DCA to AV-treated mice (Figures 7B–7D) or GF mice (Figures 7E–7H) prior to CHIKV infection resulted in reduced viral titers in serum and peripheral blood leukocytes and restored type I IFN responses at 1 dpi. The ability of C. scindens colonization and DCA treatment to decrease viremia of AV-treated mice depended on MyD88 expression, because the effect was lost in Myd88−/− mice (Figure 7I). Moreover, DCA administration to AV-treated mice reestablished IFN responses in pDCs at 1 dpi (Figure 7J). Last, DCA treatment of non-Abx-treated mice decreased viral burden in the serum, peripheral blood leukocytes, and spleen compared to non-DCA treated controls (Figures 7K–7M). These results demonstrate a functional role for microbiome-derived secondary BA in promoting MyD88-dependent type I IFN responses that limit CHIKV infection in circulation even in the context of an unperturbed microbiome.

    Discussion

    We have established a previously unknown role for the intestinal microbiome in promoting antiviral responses to alphavirus infection. Our study demonstrates that: (1) loss of the microbiome leads to increases in alphavirus burden in the blood and spleen as early as 24 h post-inoculation due to enhanced infection of circulating monocytes; (2) microbiome depletion results in blunted systemic production of type I IFN, which we link to altered MyD88 signaling in pDCs, and renders circulating monocytes more susceptible to infection; and (3) colonization of mice with a single bacterial species, C. scindens and its derived secondary BA, can restore MyD88-dependent type I IFN responses in pDCs and reduce CHIKV viremia, dissemination, and limit transmission to a primary mosquito vector.
    A growing literature suggests the intestinal microbiome can shape antiviral immune responses at distant sites. Abx-treated or GF mice have defects in innate and adaptive immune responses following infections with lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, influenza virus, murine cytomegalovirus, hepatitis B virus, or flaviviruses (Abt et al., 2012

    In summary, our detailed mechanistic analysis demonstrates how particular immune cells and signaling pathways are modulated by the microbiome to limit alphavirus infection in circulating immune cells and subsequent dissemination. The finding that a specific bacterium and its associated metabolites can restrict alphavirus dissemination may provide insight into the variability of clinical disease in humans and enable approaches for mitigating alphavirus infection outcome and possibly, its transmission to mosquito vectors and epidemic spread.

    Method Details

    Abx treatment

    Cages of mice were treated ad lib at 3 to 4 weeks of age with an oral Abx cocktail (1 g/L ampicillin (A) and 0.5 g/L vancomycin (V); from Sigma) in 20 g/L grape Kool-Aid (Kraft Foods) or with Kool-Aid (vehicle) alone. Cages, food, and water were autoclaved and mice were handled in sterile hoods. For most experiments, mice received oral Abx for 3 days as indicated in Figure 1A. For experiments involving colonization with C. scindens, C. clostridiforme, and E. faecalis, mice received oral Abx for 5 days.

    Fecal microbial transfer

    Fecal contents from mice were collected, diluted in PBS + 10% glycerol, homogenized, and clarified by passing the contents through a 100-uM filter. Aliquots were frozen on dry-ice and stored at −80°C. Mice were gavaged with 108 colony-forming units (CFU) in 100 uL of sterile PBS.

    DCA supplementation

    Sodium deoxycholate (DCA: 0.2%; Sigma 30970) was added to the drinking water for 1 week prior to infection with CHIKV.

    16S rDNA qPCR

    Fecal samples were harvested into 2 mL tubes (Sarstedt) with 1 mm diameter zirconia/silica beads (Biospec). Fecal pellets were frozen in dry ice, and stored at −80°C. Nucleic acid was extracted from fecal pellets as described previously (Baldridge et al., 2015
    2.
    Baldridge, M.T. ∙ Nice, T.J. ∙ McCune, B.T. ...

    16S rDNA amplicon sequencing and analyses

    Bar-coded PCR primers targeting the V4 region of bacterial 16S rRNA genes were used to generate amplicons from nucleic acid isolated from fecal pellets (Baldridge et al., 2015

    8.

ASVs were aligned using an R implementation of MSA (Bodenhofer et al., 2015

    Measurement of viral burden

    CHIKV- or MAYV-infected mice were euthanized at 1, 2, 3, or 28 dpi and perfused extensively with 20 mL of PBS. Spleen, ipsilateral, and contralateral ankle tissues were harvested, weighed, and homogenized with zirconia beads in a MagNA Lyser instrument (Roche Life Science) in 500 μL of DMEM media supplemented with 2% heat-inactivated FBS. For viral burden analysis in serum, blood was collected and clotted at room temperature and serum was separated. For viral burden analysis of peripheral blood leukocytes, blood was collected and erythrocytes were lysed with ammonium chloride potassium (ACK) lysis buffer (GIBCO). Remaining cells were resuspended in RNA lysis buffer. For viral burden analysis of mosquitos, bodies or heads were homogenized at 26 Hz for 4 minutes in L15 media. All tissue homogenates were clarified by centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 5 min and stored at −80°C. RNA was extracted using an Applied Biosystems 5x MagMax RNA 96 viral isolation kit (Thermo Scientific) and a Kingfisher duo prime extraction machine (Thermo Scientific). For some samples, viral burden was determined by FFA on Vero cells as described (Fox et al., 2015
    23.
    Fox, J.M. ∙ Long, F. ∙ Edeling, M.A. ...

    ).     Histology and RNA in situ hybridization

    Four-week-old vehicle or AV-treated WT mice were inoculated subcutaneously in the foot with 103 FFU of CHIKV LR 2006. At 3 dpi, animals were euthanized and perfused extensively with PBS. Spleens were harvested and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) for 24 h. Tissues were embedded in paraffin, and sections were stained with hematoxylin and eosin. RNA in situ hybridization was performed using the RNAscope 2.5 HD Assay (Brown Kit) according to the manufacturer’s instructions (Advanced Cell Diagnostics). Briefly, sections were deparaffinized, treated with H2O2 and Protease Plus prior to probe hybridization. A probe specifically targeting the CHIKV RNA (strain La Reunion) (Advanced Cell Diagnostics, 481891) was custom-designed and used for in situ hybridization experiments. Tissues were counterstained with Gill’s hematoxylin. An uninfected mouse was used as a negative control and stained in parallel. Tissue sections were visualized using a Nikon Eclipse microscope equipped with an Olympus DP71 color camera.

    Flow cytometry and cell sorting

    Peripheral blood and spleens of CHIKV-infected mice were harvested after perfusion with PBS. Splenocytes were obtained by generating a single cell suspension and passaging it through a 70-μm filter. Erythrocytes were lysed with ammonium chloride potassium (ACK) lysis buffer (GIBCO), and remaining cells were resuspended in PBS supplemented with 2% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1 mM EDTA and maintained on ice. To analyze levels of viral antigen on the surface of different cell subsets, after blockade of Fcγ receptors with anti-CD16/32 (eBioscience; clone 93) and staining for viability (eBioscience; FVD eFluor 506), staining for cell surface antigens CD45 BUV395, CD3 BUV737, CD19 PE, CD115 APC-Cy7, Ly6G BV650, Ly6C Pacific Blue, CD11b PE/Dazzle 594, CD11c PE-Cy7, MHC II AF700, NK1.1 BV785, and CD43 FITC was performed.     Bacterial culture experiments

    Frozen FMT stocks were thawed and cultivated for 48 h in liquid Brain Heart Infusion Media under strict anaerobic conditions (Coy Laboratory Products Anaerobic Vinyl Chamber). CFU count was determined by OD 600, and approximately 109 CFU of bacteria was administered per mouse. C. scindens, E. faecalis, and C. clostridioforme were obtained originally from the American Type Culture Collection. C. scindens and C. clostridioforme were grown in chopped meat media broth for 48 h under anaerobic conditions. E. faecalis was grown in chopped meat media broth for 48 h under aerobic conditions. C. scindens and E. faecalis were administered orally at 108 CFU of bacteria per mouse one day after cessation of Abx treatment. C. clostridioforme was administered orally at 109 CFU of bacteria per mouse one and two days post-cessation of Abx treatment.

    Adoptive transfer experiments

    Splenocytes were isolated from uninfected CCR2-GFP mice and CD11b+ Ly6C+GFP+ cells were sorted on a BD FACS Aria II. Cells (2 × 106) were transferred intravenously into either AV- or vehicle-treated WT recipient mice. Eighteen hours later recipient mice were infected subcutaneously with CHIKV. At 1 day post-CHIKV infection, viral antigen staining using CHK-152 and CHK-166 was determined in the spleen by flow cytometry as described above following enrichment for CD11b+ cells using anti-CD11b+ microbeads (Milliteyni). Transferred cells were identified as GFP+CD11b+.

    IFN-γ neutralization and measurements

    AV- and vehicle-treated WT and Ifnar1−/− mice were treated with an anti-IFN-γ blocking monoclonal antibody (200 ug, mAb H22; Leinco, I-438) or an IgG isotype control antibody (200 ug mAb PIP; Leinco, I-140) 1 day prior to infection with CHIKV as previously published (Harty et al., 1992

    Bone marrow chimeras

    Chimeric mice were generated by using modifications to a published protocol (Nair et al., 2017

    Nair, S. ∙ Poddar, S. ∙ Shimak, R.M. ...

    Type I IFN bioassay

    Levels of biologically active type I IFN in serum were determined using an encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV) L929 cell cytopathic effect bioassay as described previously (Sheehan et al., 2006

    Sheehan, K.C. ∙ Lai, K.S. ∙ Dunn, G.P. ...

    , 2015

    ). Briefly, serum was diluted serially in DMEM containing 10% FBS and applied in duplicate to L929 cells (2 × 104 cells/well) in 96-well plates. Following incubation for 14 h at 37°C, cells were inoculated with EMCV diluted in DMEM containing 2% FBS at a MOI of 7. At 8 h post-infection, IFN-mediated protection was assayed using CellTiter 96 aqueous cell proliferation assay as per the manufacturer’s protocol (Promega). IFN levels were calculated from an IFN-β standard curve. To ensure protection from EMCV-induced death was due to type I IFN activity, L929 cells also were pre-treated with an anti-Ifnar1 mAb (MAR-1-5A3, 50 ug/mL) prior to the addition of serum samples.

    pDC ex vivo stimulation

    Splenic and bone-marrow-derived pDCs were isolated and after blockade of Fcγ receptors with anti-CD16/32 (eBioscience; clone 93), cells were stained for viability (eBioscience; FVD eFluor 506) and with B220 BV711, PDCA-1 FITC, Siglec H APC, and LyC6 Pacific. Primary cells were cultured in complete RPMI 1640 with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 1% glutamax, 1% nonessential amino acids, 1% sodium pyruvate, 1% penicillin-streptomycin, and 1 uM β-mercaptoethanol (GIBCO-Invitrogen). Sorted pDCs were stimulated overnight with CpGA 2216 (6 μg/ml, Operon) ; CpGB 1826 (6 μg/ml, Operon) or Imiquimod (6 μM, InvivoGen). IL-6 and IFN-α levels were measured by ELISA in the cell supernatant at 18 h post-stimulation.

    Gene expression analysis

    RNA was isolated from sorted peripheral blood monocytes using the MagMAX mirVana Total RNA Isolation Kit as per manufacturer’s instructions. Gene expression levels of Bst2, Isg15, Ifnb, Ifna4, Rsad2, Ifit3, and Ifitm3 were determined via qRT-PCR and normalized to GAPDH expression.
    RNA was isolated from splenic pDCs using the MagMAX mirVana Total RNA Isolation Kit as per manufacturer’s instructions and for RNA analysis, 100 ng total RNA was hybridized to a nCounter® Mouse Immunology Panel (XT-CSO-MIM1-12) according to the manufacturer’s protocol (NanoString Technologies Inc.). The gene expression data were normalized to a set of 6 internal positive and 8 internal negative controls and then 14 internal reference genes. Values above the threshold (mean + 2SD of the negative controls) were considered for analysis. Normalized log2-transformed values were analyzed and unbiased hierarchical clustering was used to generate heatmaps in nSolver analysis software 4.0. Data is available at GEO: GSE152043.

    scRNA-seq

    Leukocytes of the peripheral blood were isolated following two rounds of ACK lysis. T and B cells were depleted using CD4, CD8, and CD19 microbeads (Millitenyi) to enrich for myeloid cells. Cells were resuspended at 100 cells/μL in PBS containing 0.04% (w/v) BSA to minimize cell loss and aggregation. ~17,500 cells were partitioned into nanoliter-scale Gel Bead-In-EMulsions (GEMs) to achieve single cell resolution for a maximum of 10,000 individual cells per sample. Utilizing the v2 Chromium Single Cell 3′ Library Kit and Chromium instrument (10x Genomics), poly-adenylated mRNA from an individual cell was tagged with a unique 16 basepair 10x barcode and 10 basepair Unique Molecular Identifier. Full length cDNA was amplified to generate sufficient mass for library construction. Enzymatic fragmentation and size selection were used to optimize the cDNA amplicon size (~400 basepair) for the library. The final library was sequence-ready and contained four unique sample indexes. The concentration of the 10x single cell library was determined through qPCR (Kapa Biosystems). The libraries were normalized, pooled, and sequenced with a custom recipe (26-8-98) on the HiSeq4000 platform (Illumina). Five single cell libraries were sequenced across an entire HiSeq4000 flow cell targeting ~45,000 reads per cell.

    Alignment, Barcode Assignment and Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) Counting

    The Cell Ranger Single-Cell Software Suite (version 3.0.2) (https://support.10xgenomics.com/single-cell-gene-expression/software/pipelines/latest/what-is-cell-ranger) was used to perform sample demultiplexing, barcode processing, and single-cell 3′ counting. Cellranger mkfastq was used to demultiplex raw base call files from the HiSeq4000 sequencer into sample-specific fastq files. Files was demultiplexed with 98%+ perfect barcode match, and 74%+ q30 reads. Subsequently, fastq files for each sample were processed with cellranger counts to align reads to the mm10 mouse genome. The default estimated cell count value of 7,000 was used for this experiment. Samples were subsampled to have equal numbers of confidently mapped reads per cell. After filtration and cluster removal total cells count was 4,695.

    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) was used. Cell Ranger filtered genes by barcode expression matrices were used as analysis inputs. Samples were pooled together using the merge function. The fraction of mitochondrial genes was calculated for every cell, and cells with a mitochondrial fraction > 5% or less than 150 gene reads were filtered out. Two sources of unwanted variation (UMI counts and the fraction of mitochondrial reads) were removed with RegressOut function. Expression measurements for each cell were normalized by total expression and then scaled to 10,000, after that log normalization was performed.

    Dimensionality Reduction and Clustering

    The most variable genes were detected using FindVariableGenes function. PCA was done only using these genes. Cells are represented with t-SNE (t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding) plots. We applied RunTSNE function to normalized data, using first 20 PCA components. For clustering, we used function FindClusters tat implements SNN (shared nearest neighbor) modularity optimization based clustering algorithm on 20 PCA components with a resolution of 0.3 Seven clusters were detected, one of which contained poorly covered cells (lower number of UMIs and detected genes); this cluster was excluded from further analysis. Four clusters were filtered out based off expression of Adgre1 and Saa3, representing macrophage contamination due to the method of sample collection.

    Identification of Cluster-Specific Genes and Marker-Based Classification

    To identify marker genes, FindAllMarkers function was used with likelihood-ratio test for single cell gene expression. For each cluster only genes that were expressed in more than 25% of cells with at least 0.25-fold difference were considered. To characterize clusters, we used the following markers: T cells: Cd3d; NK cells: Ncr1; B cells: Cd79a; neutrophils: S100a8; monocyte/myeloid cells: Csf1r, Ly6c2, Cd209a, Cx3cr1.

    Single Cell RNA-Seq Differential Expression

    To obtain differential expression between cells derived from AV-treated or vehicle-treated groups at 1 dpi a MAST test was performed and P value adjustment was performed using a Bonferroni correction (Finak et al., 2015
    21.
    Finak, G. ∙ McDavid, A. ∙ Yajima, M. ...
    MAST: a flexible statistical framework for assessing transcriptional changes and characterizing heterogeneity in single-cell RNA sequencing data
    Genome Biol. 2015; 16:278
    Crossref
    Scopus (1478)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).

    Mass spectrometry

    Fecal samples collected at indicated time points were frozen and store in −80°C until further analysis. Samples were extracted at a concentration of 200 mg/mL in 80% methanol containing 1 μM of the internal standard, d4-deoxycholate in a tissue lyserII. Samples were clarified by centrifugation then filtered through 8.0 μm PES spin filters to remove particulates. Samples (2 μl) were loaded onto a 0.5 × 150 mm custom packed C18 column using 0.1% formic acid in water (A) and 0.1% acetonitrile (B). The gradient started at 2% (B) and continued up to three min followed by a ramp to 100% (B) in over 10 min, with a hold at 100% (B) for 3 min then ramp back down to 2% (B) over three min. The column was then re-equilibrated for 11 min. Data were recorded in negative mode with MS only scan type using a Q-Exactive plus mass spectrometer set to a resolution setting of 70,000 and scan range extending from 200 to 500 daltons. The data were integrated using the QuanBroswer application of Xcalibur. The concentrations are calculated based on comparison to the internal standards and plotting against a calibration curve made from external standard concentrations ranging from 0.075 to 100 mmol. All the mass spectrometry procedures including homogenization of fecal samples were randomized by independent investigators blinded to the treatment.

    Mosquitoes and oral infection

    Blood was collected at 1 dpi from CHIKV-infected mice, snap-frozen, and stored at −80 C in heparan-treated tubes. Frozen viremic blood was used as the source of infectious virus for per os infection of Aedes albopictus (Park et al., 2018
    65.
    Park, S.L. ∙ Huang, Y.S. ∙ Higgs, S. ...
    Application of a Nonpaper Based Matrix to Preserve Chikungunya Virus Infectivity at Ambient Temperature
    Vector Borne Zoonotic Dis. 2018; 18:278-281
    Crossref
    Scopus (2)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Six-to-ten-day-old female mosquitoes were deprived of sugar for 24 hours and orally exposed to infectious blood meals supplemented with 3 mM of adenosine triphosphate as a phagostimulant (Huang et al., 2017
    36.
    Huang, Y.S. ∙ Lyons, A.C. ∙ Hsu, W.-W. ...
    Differential outcomes of Zika virus infection in Aedes aegypti orally challenged with infectious blood meals and infectious protein meals
    PLoS ONE. 2017; 12:e0182386
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Engorged mosquitoes were sorted and maintained under previously described conditions (Pal et al., 2014
    64.
    Pal, P. ∙ Fox, J.M. ∙ Hawman, D.W. ...
    Chikungunya viruses that escape monoclonal antibody therapy are clinically attenuated, stable, and not purified in mosquitoes
    J. Virol. 2014; 88:8213-8226
    Crossref
    Scopus (62)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Individual mosquitoes were cold anesthetized to separate the head and the rest of carcass. Samples were collected in L-15 media, homogenized at 26 Hz for 4 minutes and pelleted at 10,000 RPM. for 10 minutes. Viral burden was determined using RT-qPCR and median tissue culture infectious dose titration methods.

    Quantification and Statistical Analysis

    Statistical significance was assigned with P values of < 0.05 using GraphPad Prism version 8.0 (La Jolla, CA). The specific test for each dataset is indicated in respective figure legends and was selected by the number of comparison groups and variance of the data. For some virological and immune cell analysis, significance was determined by one-way ANOVA with Tukey’s post-test. For other viral burden experiments, if data points were of unequal variance, a Kruskal-Wallis ANOVA with Dunn’s post-test or Mann-Whitney test was used, depending on the number of comparison groups.

    Manage Consent Preferences

    Strictly Necessary Cookies

    Always active

    These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

    Functional Cookies

    These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.

    Performance Cookies

    These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site.

    Targeting Cookies

    These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
